repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: stylua doesn't enforce this does it?
It doesn't but I changed it for consistency with what `_print_snapshot()` spits out for the `expect()` call. Do we have a preference? (Mine is with `()`).
`expect{` is 3x more common than `expect({` so I guess our preference is `expect{`.
On the other hand `expect([[` is 1000x more common than `expect [[`.

The preference from `expect{` over `expect({` comes from that before https://github.com/luukvbaal/neovim/commit/e2224a7933b6e30ab6efb0b7ad4e3f26da57c226#diff-0c9d16bdec23e5efb43eb803e955e6ed543bb9356aa11bec3bac70177b4586c8L1699 the suggested snapshot was printed in that format. Admittedly also a PR of mine, the changes here are a continuation of that. We either go with this or a consistent reversal to without `()` I guess.
My sense from observing other core contributors is that `expect{` is preferred
Because that's the current output of `snapshot_util()`...

Not current but before #28088, I added it there because I thought we preferred that. Call parentheses seem much more prevalent in `runtime/lua` (if not enforced?), it's only in `test/` that they are omitted sometimes (not just `expect`).

comment_regular_data.body: Unlikely to get all the way there without rolling a custom `vim.inspect` that follows stylua, but this at least gets us closer. Currently the no ext_state case always bites me for no reason when I forget to run stylua.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: test(screen): adjust screen state to more closely follow stylua
